title: 1  Bayesian Thinking and Everyday Reasoning
text:
1.1 Questions

1.1.1 Rewrite the following statements as equations using the mathematical notation you learned in this chapter:

The probability of rain is low

\(P(rain) = low\)

The probability of rain given that it is cloudy is high

\(P(rain|cloud) = high\)

The probability of you having an umbrella given it is raining is much greater than the probability of you having an umbrella in general.

\(P(umbrella|rain) >> P(umbrella)\)

1.1.1.1 Organize the data you observe in the following scenario into a mathematical notation, using the techniques we’ve covered in this chapter. Then come up with a hypothesis to explain this data:

You come home from work and notice that your front door is open and the side window is broken. As you walk inside, you immediately notice that your laptop is missing.

\(D = \text{door open, window broken, laptop missing}\)
\(H_1 = \text{you've been robbed}\)
\(P(D|H_1)\)



1.1.2 The following scenario adds data to the previous one. Demonstrate how this new information changes your beliefs and come up with a second hypothesis to explain the data, using the notation you’ve learned in this chapter.

A neighborhood child runs up to you and apologizes profusely for accidentally throwing a rock through your window. They claim that they saw the laptop and didn’t want it stolen so they opened the front door to grab it, and your laptop is safe at their house.

\(H_2 = \text{child accidentally broke your window and took the laptop for safekeeping}\)
\(P(H_2| D) >> P(H_1|D)\)

title: 2  Measuring Uncertainty
text:
2.1 Questions

2.1.1 What is the probability of rolling two six-sided dice and getting a value greater than 7?

from sympy import *

x, y = symbols('x y')
event = (x + y) > 7
sample_space = [(i, j) for i in range(1, 7) for j in range(1, 7)]
prob = len([roll for roll in sample_space if event.subs({x: roll[0], y: roll[1]})]) / len(sample_space)

print(f"{round(prob,4) * 100}%")

41.67%




2.1.2 What is the probability of rolling three six-sided dice and getting a value greater than 7?

x, y, z = symbols('x y z')
event = (x + y + z) > 7
sample_space = [(i, j, k) for i in range(1, 7) for j in range(1, 7) for k in range(1, 7)]

prob = len([roll for roll in sample_space if event.subs({x: roll[0], y: roll[1], z: roll[2]})]) / len(sample_space)

print(f"{round(prob,4) * 100}%")

83.8%




2.1.3 The Yankees are playing the Red Sox. You’re a diehard Sox fan and bet your friend they’ll win the game. You’ll pay your friend $30 if the Sox lose and your friend will have to pay you only $5 if the Sox win. What is the probability you have intuitively assigned to the belief that the Red Sox will win?

\(O(\text{Red Sox win}) = \frac{30}{5} = 6\)


\(P(\text{Red Sox win}) = \frac{O(\text{Red Sox win})}{1 + O(\text{Red Sox win})} = \text{86\%}\)


\(O(\text{Red Sox win}) = \frac{.86}{1-.86} = \approx{6}\)

title: 3  Logic of Uncertainty
text:
3.1 Questions

3.1.1 What is the probability of rolling a 20 three times in a row on a 20-sided die?

from sympy import *

Rational(1,20) ** 3

\(\displaystyle \frac{1}{8000}\)




3.1.2 The weather report says there’s a 10 percent chance of rain tomorrow, and you forget your umbrella half the time you go out. What is the probability that you’ll be caught in the rain without an umbrella tomorrow?

round(Rational(1/10) * Rational(1/2),2)

\(\displaystyle 0.05\)




3.1.3 Raw eggs have a 1/20,000 probability of having salmonella. If you eat two raw eggs, what is the probability you ate a raw egg with salmonella?

p_salmonella = Rational(1/20000)
p_either = p_salmonella * 2
p_both = p_salmonella ** 2
round(p_either - p_both,4)

\(\displaystyle 0.0001\)




3.1.4 What is the probability of either flipping two heads in two coin tosses or rolling three 6s in three six-sided dice rolls?

p_heads = Rational(1,2)
p_two_heads = p_heads ** 2

p_six = Rational(1,6)
p_three_six = p_six ** 3

p_three_six_or_two_heads = p_two_heads + p_three_six
p_three_six_and_two_heads = p_two_heads * p_three_six

round(p_three_six_or_two_heads - p_three_six_and_two_heads,4)

\(\displaystyle 0.2535\)

title: 4  Creating a Binomial Probability Distribution
text:
4.1 Questions

4.1.1 What are the parameters of the binomial distribution for the probability of rolling either a 1 or a 20 on a 20-sided die, if we roll the die 12 times?
\(n = 12\)
\(k = 1\)
\(p = \frac{2}{20} = 10\%\)


4.1.2 There are four aces in a deck of 52 cards. If you pull a card, return the card, then reshuffle and pull a card again, how many ways can you pull just one ace in five pulls?


from sympy import binomial

binomial(5,1)

5




4.1.3 For the example in question 2, what is the probability of pulling five aces in 10 pulls (remember the card is shuffled back in the deck when it is pulled)?

pbinom(q=5, size=10, prob=1/13,lower.tail=FALSE)

[1] 3.313921e-05



from scipy.stats import binom

# Calculate binomial probability using survival function (equivalent to lower.tail = FALSE)
binom.sf(5, 10, 1/13 )

3.313920628846008e-05




4.1.4 When you’re searching for a new job, it’s always helpful to have more than one offer on the table so you can use it in negotiations. If you have a 1/5 probability of receiving a job offer when you interview, and you interview with seven companies in a month, what is the probability you’ll have at least two competing offers by the end of that month?

pbinom(q=1, size=7, prob=1/5, lower.tail=FALSE)

[1] 0.4232832



from scipy.stats import binom

binom.sf(1, 7, 1/5)

0.42328320000000025




4.1.5 You get a bunch of recruiter emails and find out you have 25 interviews lined up in the next month. Unfortunately, you know this will leave you exhausted, and the probability of getting an offer will drop to 1/10 if you’re tired. You really don’t want to go on this many interviews unless you are at least twice as likely to get at least two competing offers. Are you more likely to get at least two offers if you go for 25 interviews, or stick to just 7?

interviews_25 = pbinom(1, 25,1/10, lower.tail = FALSE)
interviews_7 = pbinom(1, 7,1/5, lower.tail = FALSE)
interviews_25 / interviews_7

[1] 1.721765

interviews_25 / interviews_7 >= 2

[1] FALSE



from scipy.stats import binom

prob_25 = binom.sf(1, 25, 1/10)
prob_7 = binom.sf(1, 7,  1/5)

# Calculate the ratio and check if it is greater than or equal to 2
print(prob_25 / prob_7)

1.7217647512082523

print(prob_25 / prob_7 >= 2)

False

title: 5  Beta Distribution
text:
5.1 Questions

5.1.1 You want to use the beta distribution to determine whether or not a coin you have is a fair coin—meaning that the coin gives you heads and tails equally. You flip the coin 10 times and get 4 heads and 6 tails. Using the beta distribution, what is the probability that the coin will land on heads more than 60 percent of the time?


import scipy.stats as stats

# parameters for the Beta distribution
alpha = 5
beta = 7

# calculate the probability that p > 0.6
1 - stats.beta.cdf(0.6, alpha, beta)

0.09935257600000003




from sympy import symbols, integrate
from sympy.stats import Beta, density

# symbols
p = symbols('p')

# parameters for the Beta distribution
alpha = 5
beta = 7

# create the Beta random variable
X = Beta('X', alpha, beta)

# calculate the probability that p > 0.6
prob = integrate(density(X)(p), (p, 0.6, 1))

# compute and print the result
prob.evalf()

0.0993525759999689



# Parameters for the Beta distribution
alpha <- 5
beta <- 7

# Function representing the Beta distribution
f <- function(p) {dbeta(p, shape1 = alpha, shape2 = beta)}

# Integrate the function from 0.6 to 1 (the probability of p > 0.6)
integrate(f, lower = 0.6, upper = 1)

0.09935258 with absolute error < 1.1e-15




5.1.2 You flip the coin 10 more times and now have 9 heads and 11 tails total. What is the probability that the coin is fair, using our definition of fair, give or take 5 percent?


import scipy.stats as stats

# parameters for the Beta distribution
alpha = 10
beta = 12

# calculate the probability that p is between 0.45 and 0.55
stats.beta.cdf(0.55, alpha, beta) - stats.beta.cdf(0.45, alpha, beta)

0.32758551070685515



# Parameters for the Beta distribution
alpha <- 10
beta <- 12

# Function representing the Beta distribution
f <- function(p) {dbeta(p, shape1 = alpha, shape2 = beta)}

# Integrate the function from 0.45 to 0.55 (the probability of 0.45 < p < 0.55)
integrate(f, lower = 0.45, upper = 0.55)

0.3275855 with absolute error < 3.6e-15




5.1.3 Data is the best way to become more confident in your assertions. You flip the coin 200 more times and end up with 109 heads and 111 tails. Now what is the probability that the coin is fair, give or take 5 percent?


import scipy.stats as stats

# parameters for the Beta distribution
alpha = 110
beta = 112

# calculate the probability that p is between 0.45 and 0.55
stats.beta.cdf(0.55, alpha, beta) - stats.beta.cdf(0.45, alpha, beta)

0.8607678167798964



# Parameters for the Beta distribution
alpha <- 110
beta <- 112

# Function representing the Beta distribution
f <- function(p) {dbeta(p, shape1 = alpha, shape2 = beta)}

# Integrate the function from 0.45 to 0.55 (the probability of 0.45 < p < 0.55)
integrate(f, lower = 0.45, upper = 0.55)

0.8607678 with absolute error < 9.6e-15

title: 6  Conditional Probability
text:
6.1 Questions

6.1.1 What piece of information would we need in order to use Bayes’ theorem to determine the probability that someone in 2010 who had GBS also had the flu vaccine that year?
\[
P(GBS | \text{flu vaccine}) =
\frac{P(flu\ vaccine) \times P(GBS | flu\ vaccine)}{P(GBS)}
\]
We need:

\(P(GBS)\)
\(P(flu\ vaccine)\)



6.1.2 What is the probability that a random person picked from the population is female and is not color blind?
\(P(female) = 0.5\)
\(P(color\ blind|female) = .005\)
\(P(\text{female, but not color blind}) = P(female) \times1 - P(color\ blind | female) = 0.5\times0.995=0.4975\)


6.1.3 What is the probability that a male who received the flu vaccine in 2010 is either color blind or has GBS?
\(P(A)=P(\text{color blind} | male)= \frac{4}{1,000}\)
\(P(B) = P(GBS|\text{flu vaccine})=\frac{3}{100,000}\)
Sum Rule:
\(P(A\text{ or }B)=P(A)+P(B)-P(A)\times P(B|A)\)
\(\frac{100,747}{25,000,000} = .00403\)

title: 7  Bayes’ Theorem with LEGO
text:
7.1 Questions

7.1.1 Use Bayes’ theorem to calculate the probability that a relative who just moved to a county in the Kansas City metropolitan area also lives in a county in Kansas.

Kansas City, despite its name, sits on the border of two US states: Missouri and Kansas



The Kansas City metropolitan area consists of 15 counties, 9 in Missouri and 6 in Kansas.
The entire state of Kansas has 105 counties and Missouri has 114.
7.1.2 

\[
P(Kansas | Kansas City) = \frac{P(Kansas) \times P(Kansas City| Kansas)}{P(Kansas City)} \\
= \frac{\frac{6}{105} \times \frac{105}{219}}{\frac{15}{219}} = \frac{2}{5}
\]


7.1.3 A deck of cards has 52 cards with suits that are either red or black. There are four aces in a deck of cards: two red and two black. You remove a red ace from the deck and shuffle the cards. Your friend pulls a black card. What is the probability that it is an ace?
\[
P(\text{ace |}\text{ black card}) = \frac{P(\text{black card |}\text{ ace)}\times P(ace)}{P(\text{black card})}\\
= \frac{\frac{2}{3} \times \frac{3}{51}}{\frac{26}{51}} = \frac{1}{13}
\]
